messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

app.py: from flask import Flask, jsonify, request
if user_id in users and contact_id in users:
return jsonify({'message': 'User or contact not found.'}), 404
if user_id in users and contact_id in users:
return jsonify({'message': 'User or contact not found.'}), 404
if user_id in users and group_id in groups:
return jsonify({'message': 'New admin not in group.'}), 404
return jsonify({'message': 'Only the group admin can promote a new admin.'}), 403
return jsonify({'message': 'User or group not found.'}), 404
if conversation_id in messages and message_index < len(messages[conversation_id]):
test_app.py: with app.app.test_request_context('/set_status_message', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'user_id': user_id, 'new_status': 'Hello, world!'}), content_type='application/json'):
with app.app.test_request_context('/update_privacy_settings', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'user_id': user_id, 'new_settings': {'show_email': False}}), content_type='application/json'):
with app.app.test_request_context('/block_contact', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'user_id': user_id, 'contact_id': contact_id}), content_type='application/json'):
with app.app.test_request_context('/unblock_contact', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'user_id': user_id, 'contact_id': contact_id}), content_type='application/json'):
with app.app.test_request_context('/create_group', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'group_name': 'Test Group', 'admin_id': admin_id}), content_type='application/json'):
with app.app.test_request_context('/manage_group', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'user_id': user_id, 'group_id': group_id, 'action': 'add'}), content_type='application/json'):
with app.app.test_request_context('/manage_group', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'user_id': user_id, 'group_id': group_id, 'action': 'remove'}), content_type='application/json'):

with app.app.test_request_context('/send_message', method='POST', data=json.dumps({'conversation_id': conversation_id, 'sender_id': sender_id, 'message_content': 'Hello, world!', 'message_type': 'text'}), content_type='application/json'):

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the basic structure of the application. This includes creating the main application file (app.py) and setting up a Flask application. Also, create a 'users' dictionary to act as a mock database for storing user information. The dictionary should have keys as user IDs and values as another dictionary containing user details such as email, password, profile picture, status message, privacy settings, blocked contacts, and groups. Write tests to ensure that the application setup is correct and the 'users' dictionary is functioning as expected.

Step 2: Implement the user registration and authentication features. This includes creating routes for sign up and forgotten password recovery. The sign up route should accept user details, generate a unique user ID, and store the details in the 'users' dictionary. The forgotten password recovery route should accept a user ID and send a password reset link to the user's email. Since we can't actually send emails, just simulate this by printing a message. Write tests to ensure that the sign up and password recovery features are working correctly.

Step 3: Implement the user profile features. This includes creating routes for setting profile pictures and status messages, and updating privacy settings. The routes should accept a user ID and the new details, and update the corresponding entries in the 'users' dictionary. Write tests to ensure that the profile features are working correctly.

Step 4: Implement the contact management features. This includes creating routes for blocking/unblocking contacts and managing groups. The routes should accept a user ID and the contact or group details, and update the corresponding entries in the 'users' dictionary. Write tests to ensure that the contact management features are working correctly.

Step 5: Implement the messaging features. This includes creating routes for sending and receiving messages, updating read receipts, encrypting messages, sharing images, and supporting emojis, GIFs, and stickers. Since we can't actually send messages, just simulate this by storing messages in a 'messages' dictionary with keys as conversation IDs and values as lists of messages. Each message should be a dictionary containing the sender ID, content, type (text, image, emoji, etc.), and read receipt status. Write tests to ensure that the messaging features are working correctly.

Step 6: Implement the group chat features. This includes creating routes for creating group chats, adding/removing participants, and managing admin roles and permissions. The routes should accept a user ID and the group details, and update the corresponding entries in the 'users' and 'messages' dictionaries. Write tests to ensure that the group chat features are working correctly.

Step 7: Implement the status/story feature. This includes creating routes for posting image statuses and controlling who can see the status. The routes should accept a user ID and the status details, and store the statuses in a 'statuses' dictionary with keys as user IDs and values as lists of statuses. Each status should be a dictionary containing the image, visibility settings, and expiry time. Write tests to ensure that the status/story feature is working correctly.

Step 8: Implement the web application feature. This includes creating a route for accessing the application from a browser. The route should return a simple HTML page with links to the other routes. Write tests to ensure that the web application feature is working correctly.

Step 9: Implement the connectivity and offline mode features. This includes creating a route for updating the online/offline status of a user, and storing unsent messages in a 'queue' dictionary with keys as user IDs and values as lists of messages. The route for sending messages should check the recipient's online status and either deliver the message immediately or add it to the queue. Write tests to ensure that the connectivity and offline mode features are working correctly.

Step 10: Finally, review the entire application to ensure that all features have been implemented correctly and all tests are passing. Make any necessary adjustments and write additional tests if needed. Also, create a requirements.txt file listing all the Python packages used in the project.
step: Step 7: Implement the status/story feature. This includes creating routes for posting image statuses and controlling who can see the status. The routes should accept a user ID and the status details, and store the statuses in a 'statuses' dictionary with keys as user IDs and values as lists of statuses. Each status should be a dictionary containing the image, visibility settings, and expiry time. Write tests to ensure that the status/story feature is working correctly.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
